title: Water leaking around window during rain
customer_summary: Water enters around or below a window during rain or washing.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak only happen during rain or washing?
Is the water coming from the top half of the window?
Has this window ever been removed or replaced?
steps: Inspect exterior window sealant for cracks or gaps.
Check window frame screws for looseness.
Press gently on the window frame to check for movement.
Inspect the interior wall below the window for moisture.
model_year_notes: Sealant shrinkage is common after several years.
Previous window removal increases leak risk.
stop_and_escalate: Soft wall or floor below window
next_step: Remove and reseal the window properly if sealant failure is confirmed.

yes.say: Focus inspection on exterior window sealant and upper corners.

no.say: Inspect interior condensation or plumbing sources near the window.

yes.say: Previous installation work increases likelihood of improper sealing.

no.say: Original factory sealant may have failed due to age.

title: Soft or spongy floor near bathroom or entry
customer_summary: The floor feels soft or spongy near the bathroom or entry area.
clarifying_questions: Is the soft area near plumbing fixtures?
Has there been any known water leak or overflow?
Does the soft area extend beyond one foot?
steps: Stop using nearby plumbing fixtures.
Inspect under sinks and behind access panels.
Check for swelling or discoloration at floor seams.
Map the soft area by gentle pressure.
model_year_notes: Subfloor damage often spreads beyond visible softness.
stop_and_escalate: Floor feels unsafe to walk on
next_step: Professional inspection is recommended to assess structural damage.

yes.say: Plumbing leaks are the most likely source.

no.say: Inspect exterior door seals and nearby wall penetrations.

title: Water leaking from roof vent or fan
customer_summary: Water enters from the ceiling near a roof vent, fan, or skylight.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak only occur during rain?
Is water visible at the ceiling opening?
Has the vent or fan ever been replaced?
steps: Inspect roof sealant around the vent or fan.
Check for loose or missing mounting screws.
Inspect ceiling trim for staining.
Verify water is not migrating from another roof penetration.
model_year_notes: Sealant degradation is common after 5â€“8 years.
next_step: Remove and reseal the vent or fan using approved materials.

yes.say: Roof penetration sealant failure is likely.

no.say: Inspect for condensation or water migration from another penetration.

title: Water leaking from marker or clearance lights
customer_summary: Water enters through marker or clearance lights and travels inside walls.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak appear high on the wall?
Does it only happen during rain?
Has a marker light been replaced before?
steps: Inspect exterior marker lights for cracks.
Check sealant behind the light housing.
Test the fixture for movement.
Inspect interior wall below for staining.
model_year_notes: Marker lights are one of the most common hidden leak sources.
next_step: Remove and reseal the marker light properly.

yes.say: Marker light bedding failure is very likely.

no.say: Inspect other high wall penetrations above the leak.

title: Water leaking around entry door
customer_summary: Water enters around the entry door frame during rain.
clarifying_questions: Does water pool at the bottom of the door?
Is the door difficult to close tightly?
Has the door ever been adjusted or removed?
steps: Inspect exterior door frame sealant.
Check for frame movement or gaps.
Inspect threshold and weep areas.
Inspect interior wall and floor near door.
model_year_notes: Door alignment shifts can break compression seals.
next_step: Door assembly may need removal and resealing.

yes.say: Threshold or lower frame seal failure is likely.

no.say: Inspect upper door frame corners for sealant failure.

title: Water leaking from shower pan or base
customer_summary: Water appears outside the shower during or after use.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak only occur during shower use?
Is water visible at the shower curb or base?
Has the shower pan ever been repaired?
steps: Stop using the shower immediately.
Inspect pan seams and drain area.
Check wall-to-pan joints.
Inspect floor outside shower for softness.
model_year_notes: Shower pan or drain failures cause rapid hidden damage.

yes.say: Shower pan or drain seal failure is likely.

no.say: Inspect nearby plumbing lines and wall penetrations.

title: Water leaking from front or rear shell seam
customer_summary: Water enters through the front or rear shell seam and appears inside cabinets or curved panels.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak occur after heavy rain?
Is the leak near the front or rear of the trailer?
Has seam sealant been serviced before?
steps: Inspect exterior shell seam for sealant gaps.
Check interior cabinets for staining.
Inspect curved interior panels for moisture.
Inspect roof penetrations above the seam.
next_step: Shell seam resealing may be required.

yes.say: Front or rear seam sealant failure is likely.

no.say: Inspect roof penetrations above seam area.

title: Water leaking into exterior storage compartment
customer_summary: Water collects inside an exterior storage compartment after rain.
clarifying_questions: Does water only appear after rain?
Does the hatch seal appear flattened or damaged?
Is water pooling at the bottom?
steps: Inspect hatch seal for damage.
Check frame sealant for gaps.
Clear blocked drain holes.
Inspect surrounding wall for moisture.
next_step: Replace hatch seal and reseal frame.

yes.say: Hatch seal compression failure is likely.

no.say: Inspect nearby body seams and penetrations.

title: Water leaking under sink or cabinet
customer_summary: Water is found under a sink or inside a cabinet.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak occur when the faucet is used?
Is the leak intermittent?
Has plumbing been serviced recently?
steps: Turn off water supply.
Inspect fittings and P-trap connections.
Dry area and recheck after brief use.
Inspect cabinetry for swelling.

no.say: Inspect nearby wall penetrations or drain lines.

title: Water leaking from awning or roof rail mounts
customer_summary: Water appears inside near windows below awning or roof rail mounts.
clarifying_questions: Was the awning installed aftermarket?
Is staining visible below the mounts?
Does it leak only during rain?
steps: Inspect mounting screws for looseness.
Check sealant around brackets.
Inspect interior wall below mounts.
Inspect roof rail seam above.
model_year_notes: Aftermarket installs are common leak sources.

yes.say: Awning mount penetration is a likely source.

no.say: Inspect roof seam or rail above the area.

title: Water leaking at city water inlet connection
customer_summary: Water leaks at or behind the city water inlet when connected to a hose.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak stop when water is disconnected?
Is the hose washer in good condition?
Is moisture visible inside near the inlet?
steps: Disconnect city water immediately.
Inspect hose gasket and inlet fitting.
Check inlet for cracks or looseness.
Inspect interior access area for leaks.
model_year_notes: Check valves and plastic fittings can fail with age.
next_step: Replace inlet or check valve assembly.

yes.say: External hose or gasket issue is likely.

no.say: Leak is likely behind the inlet and needs service.

title: Water leaking from black tank flush connection
customer_summary: Water leaks when using the black tank flush connection.
clarifying_questions: Does the leak occur during flush use?
Is water visible in the rear compartment?
Has the flush fitting been serviced before?
steps: Stop using the black tank flush.
Inspect hose gasket and flush inlet.
Check flush line behind access panel.
Inspect for water entering the underbelly.
model_year_notes: Flush fittings and check valves can fail or freeze-crack.
next_step: Repair or replace flush inlet or check valve.

yes.say: Flush inlet or check valve failure is likely.

no.say: Inspect flush line routing behind the wall.

title: Water dripping inside from A/C condensation
customer_summary: Water drips from the ceiling near the A/C during humid conditions without rain.
clarifying_questions: Does this happen without any rain?
Does it occur during heavy A/C use?
Is the trailer level?
steps: Confirm dripping occurs during A/C operation without rain.
Inspect roof A/C area for debris blocking drainage.
Inspect interior A/C trim for pooled water.
Verify the trailer is level.
next_step: A/C drainage or gasket service may be required.

no.say: Inspect roof sealant for possible rain intrusion.
